title: How to Keep Food Safe

steps.headline: Avoid possibly contaminated jars and cans of food.
steps.description: Don't buy cans that are leaking, bulging, or dented. Jars of food should not be cracked or have loose lids. Avoid buying jars where the button on the lid has already been popped up.

steps.headline: Don't buy hot dogs if the liquid in the package is cloudy.
Know what to look for in frozen foods.
steps.description: Frozen foods should be frozen completely solid. They should be free of ice crystals and frost, as these are signs that the food may have thawed and then been refrozen.

steps.headline: Choose your chicken wisely.
steps.description: Chicken is easily contaminated if not stored properly. Be extra careful when picking out chicken to bring home. Choose your chicken towards the end of your shopping trip. The longer it sits in your shopping cart, the more likely it will be to go bad. Choose wrapped packages without tears, holes, or leaks. The package should be cold and feel firm when lightly squeezed. Smell the chicken. If it smells spoiled, don't buy it. Check the sell-by date. Remember that this is different than the use-by date; it's okay if it's today's date. Just plan to use the chicken within two days of its sell-by date to be safe.

steps.headline: Choose your turkey wisely.
steps.description: Like chicken, turkey is easily contaminated. Be sure to choose the turkey near the end of your shopping trip to avoid contamination while it's in your cart. Find a wrapped turkey without holes, tears, or leaks. Be sure that the turkey is cold and feels firm when lightly squeezed. Choose a turkey from the bottom of the stack. Often, those that have been stacked near the top do not stay cold enough to guarantee safe eating.

methods.name: Keep Foods at a Safe Temperature

steps.headline: Check the temperature.
steps.description: Remember that hot foods should always be kept above 140˚F, refrigerated foods should be kept between 35˚F and 40˚F and freezer foods should be kept below 10˚F.

steps.headline: Don't let hot food sit at room temperature for more than 2 hours.
steps.description:
This includes prep time. If it has been that long, either reheat or refrigerate the food to lessen the possibility of contamination. Never partially cook poultry, meat, fish, or seafood and then set aside to finish later (even if you refrigerate it). This can actually aid in bacterial growth, increasing your chances of food poisoning. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/a7\/Keep-Food-Safe-Step-7Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Keep-Food-Safe-Step-7Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/a7\/Keep-Food-Safe-Step-7Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Keep-Food-Safe-Step-7Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Refrigerate hot leftovers until ready to reserve.
steps.description: This also includes takeout and leftover restaurant dishes. Break up large amounts of leftovers into many smaller containers to that they chill more quickly. When you refrigerate lots of warm leftovers, make sure to adjust the refrigerator to a slightly colder setting. Change back to the original setting after about 8 hours. Be sure to reheat the food to at least 165˚F. Use a cover to retain moisture and help heat the center of the food. All gravies should be brought to a rolling boil.

steps.headline: Thaw frozen food in the microwave or refrigerator.
steps.description: Never thaw it at room temperature. Cook immediately after thawing. If thawing in the refrigerator, allow 5 hours per 1 lb. of frozen food. If thawing in the microwave, follow the manufacturers directors.

steps.headline: Store foods in the appropriate sections of the refrigerator.
steps.description: Different parts of the fridge are slightly different temperatures, so it's important to know what to store where. Store eggs in the carton on a shelf inside the fridge. Avoid storing them in the fridge door, as this compartment doesn't get cold enough to safely preserve them. Store chicken in the meat compartment. If you don't have one, find the coldest part of the fridge and store your chicken there. Alternatively, you can freeze the chicken. Store a turkey in the coldest place it will fit. If possible, store it in a tray so that the juices don't leak onto the rest of your food.

steps.headline: Wash your hands.
steps.description: Though it may seem excessive, it's important to wash your hands before and after you handle food. This is especially important when you work with raw meat, poultry, fish, shellfish, or eggs.

steps.headline: Prepare hot, soapy water.
steps.description: Clean all utensils and surfaces immediately after contact with raw meat, poultry, fish, or seafood.

steps.headline: Clean contaminated sponges and dishcloths.
steps.description: This is most effective if you use hot, soapy water in the washing machine. You should also consider soaking them in a mixture of 3/4 cup chlorine bleach to 1 gallon (3.8 L) water.

steps.headline: Be smart while shopping.
steps.description: In your grocery cart, keep raw poultry, meat, fish, or seafood away from foods that do not need to be cooked before eating.

steps.headline: Thaw raw poultry, meat, fish, and seafood in a large tray.
steps.description: The tray should be big enough to catch any juices that may run off as a result of the defrosting process. This will prevent the juices from running and ruining other foods in your fridge. To be extra safe, place the tray on the bottom shelf of the fridge while defrosting.

steps.headline: Use separate cutting boards.
steps.description: Use a separate cutting board for raw poultry/meat/fish/seafood than you do for other ingredients. Glass or plastic cutting boards are best for cutting easily contaminated foods. Wooden ones are more porous, meaning that it's easier for the contaminated juices to get trapped in them. Consider using disposable cutting sheets when cutting raw poultry/meat/fish/seafood to protect your cutting board from contamination.

steps.headline: Wash your cutting boards well.
steps.description: As soon as possible after use, wash your cutting board in hot, soapy water or run it through the dishwasher. To be extra careful, you should also cover the board with a mixture of 1 teaspoon chlorine bleach to 1 quart water. Let stand for 2 to 3 minutes before rinsing thoroughly.

steps.headline: Insert stuffing last.
steps.description: This should be always be done immediately before cooking. Minimizing the amount of time the stuffing spends in contact with the raw meat will prevent bacteria from contaminating the stuffing.

steps.headline: Throw away leftover marinate that has come in contact with raw poultry/meat/fish/seafood.
steps.description: If you wish to serve it as sauce, bring to a rolling boil. Keeping it at a boil, stir for at least a minute before serving.

steps.headline: Keep track of your plates.
steps.description: Never put cooked food on a plate that was used for raw poultry, meat, fish, or seafood unless the plate has been thoroughly washed first.

text:
Know What's Safe to Buy Avoid possibly contaminated jars and cans of food. Don't buy cans that are leaking, bulging, or dented. Jars of food should not be cracked or have loose lids. Avoid buying jars where the button on the lid has already been popped up. Don't buy hot dogs if the liquid in the package is cloudy. Know what to look for in frozen foods. Frozen foods should be frozen completely solid. They should be free of ice crystals and frost, as these are signs that the food may have thawed and then been refrozen. Choose your chicken wisely. Chicken is easily contaminated if not stored properly. Be extra careful when picking out chicken to bring home. Choose your chicken towards the end of your shopping trip. The longer it sits in your shopping cart, the more likely it will be to go bad. Choose wrapped packages without tears, holes, or leaks. The package should be cold and feel firm when lightly squeezed. Smell the chicken. If it smells spoiled, don't buy it. Check the sell-by date. Remember that this is different than the use-by date; it's okay if it's today's date. Just plan to use the chicken within two days of its sell-by date to be safe. Choose your turkey wisely. Like chicken, turkey is easily contaminated. Be sure to choose the turkey near the end of your shopping trip to avoid contamination while it's in your cart. Find a wrapped turkey without holes, tears, or leaks. Be sure that the turkey is cold and feels firm when lightly squeezed. Choose a turkey from the bottom of the stack. Often, those that have been stacked near the top do not stay cold enough to guarantee safe eating. Keep Foods at a Safe Temperature Check the temperature. Remember that hot foods should always be kept above 140˚F, refrigerated foods should be kept between 35˚F and 40˚F and freezer foods should be kept below 10˚F. Don't let hot food sit at room temperature for more than 2 hours. This includes prep time. If it has been that long, either reheat or refrigerate the food to lessen the possibility of contamination. Never partially cook poultry, meat, fish, or seafood and then set aside to finish later (even if you refrigerate it). This can actually aid in bacterial growth, increasing your chances of food poisoning. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/a7\/Keep-Food-Safe-Step-7Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Keep-Food-Safe-Step-7Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/a7\/Keep-Food-Safe-Step-7Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Keep-Food-Safe-Step-7Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Refrigerate hot leftovers until ready to reserve. This also includes takeout and leftover restaurant dishes. Break up large amounts of leftovers into many smaller containers to that they chill more quickly. When you refrigerate lots of warm leftovers, make sure to adjust the refrigerator to a slightly colder setting. Change back to the original setting after about 8 hours. Be sure to reheat the food to at least 165˚F. Use a cover to retain moisture and help heat the center of the food. All gravies should be brought to a rolling boil. Thaw frozen food in the microwave or refrigerator. Never thaw it at room temperature. Cook immediately after thawing. If thawing in the refrigerator, allow 5 hours per 1 lb. of frozen food. If thawing in the microwave, follow the manufacturers directors. Store foods in the appropriate sections of the refrigerator. Different parts of the fridge are slightly different temperatures, so it's important to know what to store where. Store eggs in the carton on a shelf inside the fridge. Avoid storing them in the fridge door, as this compartment doesn't get cold enough to safely preserve them. Store chicken in the meat compartment. If you don't have one, find the coldest part of the fridge and store your chicken there. Alternatively, you can freeze the chicken. Store a turkey in the coldest place it will fit. If possible, store it in a tray so that the juices don't leak onto the rest of your food. Keep Your Work Space Clean Wash your hands. Though it may seem excessive, it's important to wash your hands before and after you handle food. This is especially important when you work with raw meat, poultry, fish, shellfish, or eggs. Prepare hot, soapy water. Clean all utensils and surfaces immediately after contact with raw meat, poultry, fish, or seafood. Clean contaminated sponges and dishcloths. This is most effective if you use hot, soapy water in the washing machine. You should also consider soaking them in a mixture of 3/4 cup chlorine bleach to 1 gallon (3.8 L) water. Don't Cross-Contaminate Be smart while shopping. In your grocery cart, keep raw poultry, meat, fish, or seafood away from foods that do not need to be cooked before eating. Thaw raw poultry, meat, fish, and seafood in a large tray. The tray should be big enough to catch any juices that may run off as a result of the defrosting process. This will prevent the juices from running and ruining other foods in your fridge. To be extra safe, place the tray on the bottom shelf of the fridge while defrosting. Use separate cutting boards. Use a separate cutting board for raw poultry/meat/fish/seafood than you do for other ingredients. Glass or plastic cutting boards are best for cutting easily contaminated foods. Wooden ones are more porous, meaning that it's easier for the contaminated juices to get trapped in them. Consider using disposable cutting sheets when cutting raw poultry/meat/fish/seafood to protect your cutting board from contamination. Wash your cutting boards well. As soon as possible after use, wash your cutting board in hot, soapy water or run it through the dishwasher. To be extra careful, you should also cover the board with a mixture of 1 teaspoon chlorine bleach to 1 quart water. Let stand for 2 to 3 minutes before rinsing thoroughly. Insert stuffing last. This should be always be done immediately before cooking. Minimizing the amount of time the stuffing spends in contact with the raw meat will prevent bacteria from contaminating the stuffing. Throw away leftover marinate that has come in contact with raw poultry/meat/fish/seafood. If you wish to serve it as sauce, bring to a rolling boil. Keeping it at a boil, stir for at least a minute before serving. Keep track of your plates. Never put cooked food on a plate that was used for raw poultry, meat, fish, or seafood unless the plate has been thoroughly washed first.
